prompt: What rule allows us to derive P from (P ∨ Q) and ¬Q?
hint: If one option in an 'or' is false, what can we conclude?
explanation: Disjunctive Syllogism (DS): From (P ∨ Q) and ¬Q, derive P. If 'P or Q' is true but Q is false, then P must be true. One of them has to be true!
visual_concept: Two doors: One leads to P, one to Q. Door Q is locked (false). If you must go through one, you must go through P.
